definitions.definition: to or at a lower place or position

examples.text: She jumped down off the chair.
He looked down at her.
We watched as the sun went down.
She bent down to pick up her glove.
Mary's not down yet *(= she is still upstairs)*.
The baby can't keep any food down *(= in her body)*.
I stuck the label down with sellotape.

definitions.definition: from a standing position to a sitting or lying position

examples.text: Please sit down.
He had to go and lie down for a while.

definitions.definition: at a lower level or rate

examples.text: Prices have gone down recently.
We're already two goals down *(= the other team has two goals more)*.

definitions.definition: used to show that the amount or strength of something is lower, or that there is less activity

examples.text: Turn the music down!
The class settled down and she began the lesson.

definitions.definition: on paper; on a list

examples.text: Did you get that down?
I always write everything down.
Have you got me down for the trip?

definitions.definition: reading from top to bottom, not from side to side

examples.text: I can't do 3 down.

definitions.definition: to or in the south of a country

examples.text: They flew down to Texas.
Houses are more expensive down south.

definitions.definition: from an important or famous place, especially a large city, to a smaller or less famous place

examples.text: We've got people from the head office coming down.
Her daughter's down from Oxford *(= Oxford University)* for the holidays.

definitions.definition: used to show the limits in a range or an order

examples.text: Everyone will be there, from the Principal down.

definitions.definition: having lost the amount of money mentioned

examples.text: At the end of the day we were £20 down.

definitions.definition: if you pay an amount of money down, you pay that to start with, and the rest later
used to say how far you have got in a list of things you have to do

examples.text: Well, I've seen six apartments so far. That's six down and four to go!

definitions.definition: to or at a local place such as a shop, pub, etc.

examples.text: I'm just going down to the post office.
I saw him down at the shops.

definitions.definition: used to tell an animal or person to sit or lie

examples.text: ‘Down, boy!’ she laughed as the dog jumped up to greet her.

definitions.definition: to be the responsibility of somebody

examples.text: It's down to you to check the door.

definitions.definition: to be caused by a particular person or thing

examples.text: She claimed her problems were down to the media.

definitions.definition: to have only a little money left

examples.text: I'm down to my last dollar.

definitions.definition: to have or catch an illness
behaving in an unfair or aggressive way, especially because you want to win

examples.text: The candidate again got down and dirty with his rival.
The online campaign was getting down and dirty.

definitions.definition: rude and making you feel shocked

examples.text: The singer got down and dirty at the club last night and made headlines again.
The singers are a down-and-dirty duo from Ohio.

definitions.definition: during a long period of time

examples.text: Down through the years this town has seen many changes.

definitions.definition: including every small part or detail of something

examples.text: She organized everything down to the last detail.

definitions.definition: to or in Australia and/or New Zealand
used to say that you are opposed to something, or to a person

examples.text: The crowds chanted ‘Down with NATO!’

definitions.definition: to be able to do something easily or well

examples.text: She's young and she hasn't really got it down yet.
The teacher gave us the music to the song and we had two weeks to get it down.
It looked easy once you got the system down.

definitions.definition: a person who is determined or wants something very much will succeed

wordOrigin: adverb Old English dūn, dūne, shortened from adūne ‘downward’, from the phrase of dūne ‘off the hill’.
